awd_titl_txt: Travel: Fellowships for Students from U.S. Universities to Attend ISWC 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
This travel award will fund up to 15 United States-based students attending the 23rd International Semantic Web Conference (ISWC 2024), held in Maryland, US from November 11 to 15, 2024. ISWC is the premier international forum for state-of-the-art research on all aspects of the Semantic Web, knowledge graphs, and their intersection with other domains. Student Fellowships will help cover the travel costs for United States students, making it possible for them to attend the conference and discuss and disseminate their work. They will also provide an opportunity for them to interact with future national and international scientific collaborators.

The International Semantic Web Conference, which is now in its 23rd year, is an interdisciplinary conference that includes work on Data Management, Natural Language Processing, Knowledge Representation, and Reasoning, Ontologies and Ontology Languages, Semantic Web Engineering, Linked Data, User Interfaces, and Applications. It regularly has several hundred attendees. In addition to the main technical tracks, the conference includes a variety of events that provide opportunities for more in-depth interaction amongst researchers at different institutions who are at various stages of their research careers, and researchers who are interested in many different aspects of Semantic Web Research. Students benefit from the Doctoral Consortium - a full day event where students can get critical, but encouraging, feedback on their work from senior members of the community. They also benefit from the career mentoring lunch, where experienced members of the community from both academia and industry answer questions in an informal setting. For further information see the conference web site at: https://iswc2024.semanticweb.org/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Semantic Web is an area of computer science research that investigates a next-generation infrastructure for the World Wide Web that is equally accessible, understandable, and reasonable for humans and machines alike. The 2024 edition of the International Semantic Web Conference (ISWC) took place in Baltimore, Maryland, United States. https://iswc.umbc.edu/

The provided funds supported thirteen students to attend the conference, with the selection process managed by the student grant chairs Roberto Yus (UMBC, USA), Diego Torres (Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Argentina), and Veruska Zamborlini (Universidade Federal do Espírito Santo, Brazil). Applicants submitted details such as their university, program, academic level, conference contributions (e.g., papers or posters), institutional funding, and requested amounts. Letters of recommendation from their advisors were also required.

Students were ranked based on their participation level, prioritizing those with full conference papers, followed by workshop papers or doctoral consortium proposals, and then poster presenters. First-time attendees from minority groups without institutional funding were given special consideration. Ultimately, eight graduate students in the top category received $2,000 each, while five others, including some without conference papers, were awarded amounts between $700 and $1,500. Unfortunately, one student had to cancel attendance due to unforeseen circumstances.

Supported students expressed deep appreciation for the travel funding, noting its critical role in enabling them to present research, share ideas, and engage with the Semantic Web community. They contributed various papers to conference tracks and workshops, enhancing the success of ISWC 2024. The grant also facilitated meaningful interactions with senior researchers and peers, helping students refine their research and communication skills. They also had the opportunity to interact with other students who were able to attend the conference thanks to the support of the Semantic Web Science Association (SWSA). Overall, 36 students received travel grants funded by the NSF and SWSA. This support allowed many, including those from U.S.-based institutions, to attend and actively participate in the conference. The experience fostered academic growth and collaboration. See photos featuring all the students who received a travel grant with the conference organizers and keynote speaker Dr. Chaitan Baru from NSF.



 

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2025
Modified by: Roberto Yus
